docs.lead_paragraph: WE knew what we wanted when we were planning our vacation last summer, but we were not sure where to find it on this side of the ocean. The previous year, my wife, Laura, and I rented a cottage on the outskirts of a golden hilltop village in southern France. We drove through mountainous countryside to shop at markets in the morning, played cards in the afternoon sun and cooked salmon on one of the world's worst electric grills at night. It was the best vacation I ever had.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT has taken more than 30 years, but Asbury Park, N.J., crushed by race riots that drove out its middle class and sent it into a tailspin of poverty and municipal corruption, is seeing recovery, sometimes dramatic, in some of its neighborhoods. Fueled by an influx of gays, empty nesters and rock fans, property prices are booming in parts of the city, and stores are opening. But the recovery is still fragile. There is little foot traffic on Cookman Avenue, the main business street, and more than half the stores are vacant, with their windows boarded up, soaped up or cracked. Looming northward in the distance, at the oceanfront, is the rusting skeleton of an unfinished 11-story luxury high-rise -- a relic of a failed redevelopment effort started in the late 1980's.

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In/Asbury Park; After Bleak Years, Signs of Progress

docs.lead_paragraph: SANDRA LOCHREN, a 34-year-old Southold resident, became a Suffolk County police officer in March 1993. Now she says she might have chosen a different career had she known the difficulties she would face after becoming pregnant with her second child three years ago. Instead of assigning her a desk job or some other administrative position, she was assigned to work in a patrol car. She refused and went on paid sick leave.

headline.main: U.S. Faults Suffolk On Maternity Leave

docs.abstract: Article on ruling by Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, in suit filed by six pregnant police officers, challenging Suffolk County police department's policies; EEOC has ruled that department discriminated against officers by not assigning them to light duty jobs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Yuko Suzuki went into business for herself after the advertising company she worked for went bankrupt, no amount of talk she had heard about the hardships facing professional women here prepared her for the humiliations ahead. As an independent saleswoman, she found that customers merely pretended to listen to her. Time and again when she finished a presentation, men would ask who her boss was. Eventually she hired a man to go along with her, because merely having a man by her side -- even a virtual dummy -- increased her sales significantly, if not her morale.
docs.abstract: Last of three articles in series Can Japan Change describes hardships facing professional women there; resistance to expanding women's professional roles remains high in country where economic status of women trails far behind that of women in other advanced economies; some experts say Japanese would rather let their economy stagnate than send their women up corporate ladder; although 40 percent of Japanese women work, they hold only 9 percent of managerial positions; Japanese labor economists say women's relative lack of economic participation may be shaving 0.6 percent off annual growth; others suggest country can go no further with current social model of men filling most economic, management and political roles; women seeking to break into career track must overcome entrenched biases, including feeling among managers that childbearing is insupportable disruption; women say intense competitive pressure in workplace can lead to resentment, even in progressive companies, against mothers who avail themselves of child care leave or flexible work hours; photo; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey ranked second in the nation, after Mississippi, in the proportion of babies delivered by Caesarean section, according to a new report issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. In 2002, 30.9 percent of New Jersey babies, or about 33,500, were delivered by Caesarean section. That was up from 28.9 percent the year earlier. Mark T. Olesnicky, the president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, attributed the rate to various factors, including doctors' concern about liability resulting from trauma during vaginal delivery. New York's rate is 27.2 percent and Connecticut's rate is 26.1 percent, while the national rate is 26.1 percent. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: State Is Second-Highest In Caesarean Births

docs.lead_paragraph: Hope and trepidation filled the nine-month wait Nancy and Dennis endured until they were able to bring their adopted daughter, Mira, home to New York from the orphanage in Kazakhstan that had cared for her in the first 11 months of her life. Would she be healthy? What might she have been exposed to prenatally? Alcohol? Drugs? Infections? Was she well nourished before and after birth? And did she receive the hugs and attention that every baby requires to feel secure and wanted?

headline.main: Adoptions From Afar: Rewards and Challenges

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column explores skyrocketing number of adoptions by Americans of foreign-born children and how unique circumstances can potentially impact children and families both emotionally and physically; stories; pediatrician Dr Jane Aronson's web site www.orphandoctor.com lends practical information for international adoptions and shares some potential problems; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new process involving ultrasound may soon add an important nonsurgical option to a list of less-than-perfect treatments for uterine fibroids, the noncancerous tumors that lodge in the muscle of the uterus. The technique uses focused ultrasound waves to destroy the tumors through the skin and, unlike hysterectomy, the most common treatment for fibroids, does not require hospitalization.

headline.main: Ultrasound Found Safe for Uterine Fibroid Tumors

docs.abstract: Dr Elizabeth A Stewart, Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital Center for Uterine Fibroids clinical director, publishes study in American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology that confirms safety of high intensity focused ultrasound in treating noncancerous fibroid tumors; effectiveness of procedure, known as HIFU, requires more research according to study; current treatments for fibroids are discussed and evaluated; HIFU results in Israel and Europe show promise, with Chaim Sheba Medical Center in Tel Aviv reporting that 75% of center's patients studied experienced reduction in symptoms (S)
